Yes, Canadian companies can do this too - Tina Luu Max Tims //

OMERS is a $110 billion dollar pension fund that determined that running a co-working space in a demolition-slated building that they actually own (Oxford Properties) is not a business worth continuing. So now a government funded agency (OCE) has paid them $3M to take over and run the co-working space instead. I can't help but feel for the privately operated, vibrant co-working spaces such as Workhaus, Make Lemonade Co. Ltd. Spaces. offices | co-working | meeting rooms., East Room StartWell Project Spaces, Clearspace Eureka Building + Eureka Hub even WeWork and Breather ... who are already struggling to survive in this environment and who will now find themselves competing with a huge amount of taxpayer-funded co-working space. Further, I would not categorize OneEleven as an accelerator, but rather as flexible office space for tech companies (similar to WeWork and the others). Equity is not taken in any of the companies, time-limits are not in place and investments are not made as a condition of selection. Companies pay market rent to be there. https://lnkd.in/gU4MHxv cc. Fatima Syed Claudia Krywiak Adrian Joaquin Qasim Virjee Peter Polydor David Skok Mark Goh

This morning we are kicking off Techstars Foundercon 2020. Foundercon is one of the best parts of Techstars - its our private conference and event for our global network of founders, investors and corporate partners. My first real experience with Techstars was attending a Foundercon in Cincinnati, OH several years ago. It was this experience which demonstrated to me how special Techstars really is. It was incredible to see a downtown of an American city taken over by hundreds of people wearing our (then) green t-shirts and Techstars logos. At the time we had about 1200 portfolio companies. Now we have 2300 and counting (!!). While I miss this live event (and meeting the hundreds of VC fund managers and corporate innovation leads who attend it alongside the incredible founders) and visiting cities like Berlin, Oakland, Turin and Boulder, I am happy to get a dose of a virtual Foundercon today. One day we will meet again. Good luck today and tomorrow to David Brown David Cohen Brad Feld John Hill Claudia Reuter Clement Cazalot Dan DeMers Ramzy Ismail Jag Singh Neal Sales-Griffin Natty Zola dave payne Ryan Kuder ethan austin Anna Barber Andrea Perdomo Hilla Ovil-Brenner Jenny Fielding Ted Serbinski Laura Kennedy Stacy Carter Nicole Glaros Kacey Wherley Carlos Almonte

While this panel is taking place tomorrow I really want to draw attention to the current Founder Institute Toronto class. This should make Canadians proud because, 1) it is the largest FI accelerator batch in world history - 600 past cohorts, 200 cities in 65 countries - and this is the biggest one ever, and 2) there is a remarkable level of diversity in the founder profiles with 45 of the 47 founders being either a.) a woman, b.) black, c.) an immigrant or d.) a visible minority.
Tomorrow night's session is on Product Development and our 3 mentors are all Y Combinator or Techstars alum.
Message me for the Zoom link if you want to see a bit of this in action. 630pm EST followed by the Silicon Valley dual program at 9pm EST. Jordan Jocius Lidia Bit-Yunan Ben Stacey

This article in today's Globe and Mail should lead to a lot of thought across the way our governments (federal, provincial, regional, local) fund program-delivered innovation in Canada (similar model). It would be interesting to know what percentage of announced funding goes to administer and staff the delivery organization non-profit themselves (and to use these metrics to help measure success and overall impact). As a point of reference, at Techstars we are just 2 people in Toronto (and 6 across 3 accelerators in Canada) and at Founder Institute we have 0 FTEs in Canada. "In fact, the PM had announced a $912-million program, enough for more than 180,000 volunteers, but that wasn‚Äôt going to happen. Bardish Chagger, the minister responsible, testified that WE would have received up to $43.5-million for two batches of 20,000 volunteers, plus a ‚Äúsupplemental cohort‚Äù of an unknown number. Let‚Äôs say 50,000 in all. That means the charity might have received $43.5-million to administer $250-million in grants." cc. Campbell Clark

Big congratulations to Saroop Bharwani and Nick Seelert and the team from Senso for this milestone investment. Senso is a Techstars Toronto company from our first class in 2018 and is on the verge of disrupting the mortgage space in profound ways.
There have been stories about the decline in Canadian venture capital outcomes during this pandemic. Not the case here at Techstars Toronto with 6 fundraising announcements (out of just 20 companies) since the pandemic -- Eddy Travels, Inkblot Therapy, Velocia, Doorr, Cinchy and now Senso.ai -- well done to all of these great Canadian (and soon to be Canadian) founders -- Edmundas Eddy Balƒçikonis Pranas Kiziela Adomas Baltagalvis Luke Vigeant Julie Sabine Arash Zohoor David Winterstein Hamid Akbari Muhammad Rashid Adam A. Hijleh Abbas Ali Karanjot Jaswal Dan DeMers for strong results in 2020. Onwards! More announcements to come from the alumni and the new Techstars 2020 class is as strong as ever. So many jobs being created here. #Canada #Toronto

Its Canada Day üá®üá¶ and I am particularly proud of what is being accomplished at Founder Institute Toronto. Founder Institute is the Silicon Valley-based pre-accelerator which is a proven feeder program into accelerators like Techstars, YC, Alchemist and many others. The current class in Toronto is enjoying a gap week in recognition of July 1st, but they are working hard and preparing for next week‚Äôs Mentor Idea Review (where they present to mentors and require minimum scores to proceed into the next week).

This is the largest and most diverse group of early-stage entrepreneurs ever assembled in the history of FI - which spans 11 years, 65 countries, 200 cities and 600 cohorts (so largest in the world!)

Thank you to all the mentors - many Techstars founders who are giving back to the next generation but also many other prominent and experienced tech and business leaders who have been spending time delivering sessions and hosting countless office hours listening to and helping these founders.

I expect that 40-50 new tech startups will come from this here in Canada by September 2020. More than 200 have been created so far.

Immigrants, women and black founders are the rule, not the exception. It happens organically because, well Canada üá®üá¶

The numbers behind Collision Conf are now out. Its really remarkable to see what their team did in just 3 months. I remember getting a call from Paddy Cosgrave telling me that the decision to go fully virtual had to be made. I thought about trying to talk him out of it (for Toronto) but common sense set in. For me a telling sign is how much FOMO do I feel when at a huge tech gathering (how many startups can I meet and which ones am I ignoring, which talks am I watching and how many am I missing??). This thing is online but there feelings of FOMO attacking at me. #CollisionfromHome #Techstars #FounderInstitute #Toronto

In just an hour from now I will be kicking off ‚ÄòCollision from Home‚Äô from my home. Its been many months of planning and execution by the world-class Web Summit team mostly in Dublin, Ireland and an incredible group here in Toronto. There are more than 30,000 registered delegates and the speaker list is phenomenal. But for those who know me know that its networking and connections that matter most, and the Collision mobile app and web app are lighting up now with new contacts and familiar ones. Practicing my lines a bit now... Paddy Cosgrave Casey Lau Yvonne Redmond Keith Wallace #collisionfromhome

Today was a great day. We officially kicked off our 3rd Techstars Toronto accelerator. We patiently await for this pandemic to end so that some of our new founders can make their anticipated moves to Canada (permanent moves) and for others to make their way to our downtown offices. But in spite of these temporary challenges, entrepreneurs never cease to build and advance. We have 10 incredible teams to show you. They are talented, tenacious, disruptive and diverse. Thats all we ask them to be. In 2018 just after launching Techstars in Toronto we had the opportunity to meet two somewhat introverted and quiet technical founders during some office hours. We met more than 500 entrepreneurs during that period, but something stood out about Dan DeMers and Karanjot Jaswal. They had a huge vision, highly developed software and a relentless work ethic. We knew that this was what Techstars was all about, and we shortlisted them and quickly made our investment. During the months of Techstars, the Cinchy team spent countless days and nights in a small windowless boardroom which they selected as their work area (introverts, right?). By the end of the program (and with help from the Tariq Haddadin pitch coaching regimen) Dan delivered an incredible Demo Day pitch and the ball was really rolling.

We are proud to be making our 3rd investment into Cinchy right now alongside some amazing new investors. As both Dan and Karanjot say in their blog this morning, this is just the beginning.

We are launching a very exciting new Founder Institute pre-accelerator. We are recruiting early-stage entrepreneurs (ideal for first-time founders). This program is unique because it marks the first ever jointly run accelerator between 2 of the world's leading tech ecosystems - Toronto/Waterloo and Silicon Valley. This could be history in the making. Imagine the connections that could come from this between the mentors, partners (we need some), investors and of course founders. These 40-50 new startup companies will launch in unison. This could be the new model of ecosystem building. The ask - please refer any promising entrepreneurs. Cambridge! I'm coming next week to talk all things startup marketing and positioning.

I'm doing a deep dive into:
a) A set of startup repositioning case studies where a shift in target market unlocked giant growth
b) How positioning for customers is very different from positioning for VCs and what to do to avoid the traps
c) A structured methodology for finding your best positioning and how to get it done.

Attention London startup founders! I'm coming for an event next week and we are talking all things startup positioning.

Specifically we are going to do a deep dive into:
a) how to use your market category to stand out in a crowded market
b) how smart positioning can make a confusing, highly technical product easy to understand
c)how a shift in positioning can transform the way you market and sell.

A founder‚Äôs skill is knowing how to recognize new patterns and to pivot on a dime. At times the pattern is noise, and the vision turns out to be a hallucination. Knowing how to sort between vision and hallucination can avoid chaos inside your startup.#innovation #startups #entrepreneurship #entrepreneurs #venturecapital #startupsuccess #startup

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs do something to help with the pandemic.‚Äù In April, with the economy crashing, and the East Coast in lockdown, I heard this from Stanford instructors Tom Bedecarre and Todd Basche, both on the same day. And my response to them was the same, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt sew masks and I don‚Äôt know how to make ventilators.‚Äù But after thinking about it, it dawned on to me that we could contribute ‚Äì by creating a class to help existing businesses recover and new ones to start.

And so, Hacking for Recovery began, starting first at Stanford and next offered by University of Hawaii for the State of Hawaii. Here's a look at the progress 70 teams made in the classes. #Hacking4Recovery #teaching #teachingandlearning #entrepreneurshipeducation #entrepreneurship #innovation #leanstartup #LeanLaunchPad #startupsuccess #startups
